chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management in primary care
chapter.summary: Covers the management of insect bites and stings in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Management in primary care
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For all insect bites and stings, where admission is not required:
    • Consider if tetanus prophylaxis is appropriate — for more information, see the CKS topic on Bites - human and animal.
    • If a stinger is visible in the skin - remove it as quickly as possible by scraping sideways with a fingernail, a piece of card or a credit card.
    • If a tick is visible in the skin:
      • And the person is not known to be allergic to ticks, remove the tick as soon as possible by grasping it close to skin with a pair of forceps, tweezers or specialist tick remover and pulling gently but firmly perpendicular to the skin.
      • Do not twist the tick as this may leave the mouthparts in the skin.
      • Do not use petroleum jelly, alcohol, nail polish remover, or lit matches to try and dislodge the tick as this may cause it to regurgitate potentially infectious material into bite.
      • Do not routinely offer antimicrobial prophylaxis or carry out serological tests for Lyme disease, but advise that if a rash appears at the site of the bite (erythema migrans) or a fever develops, the person should promptly seek medical advice – for more information see the CKS topic on Lyme disease.
    • Clean the area and advise the person that simple first aid measures such as the use of cold compresses may help reduce local pain and swelling.
    • Advise the person on:
      • Prevention of secondary infections with good hygiene and avoidance of itching.
      • When to seek medical help for example, if secondary infection (ongoing or worsening erythema, pain, or fever), a large local reaction or systemic reaction develops.
    • Provide the person with appropriate information on avoidance of insect bites and stings.
    • Reassess people with an insect bite or sting if they 
      • develop signs or symptoms of infection
      • have a deterioration in their condition or become systemically unwell
      • have severe pain which is significantly worse than the appearance of the wound. This may indicate the presence of toxin-producing bacteria. 
  • If bites are thought to be due to infestation with:
    • Bedbugs — advise the person to contact pest control services. Pest control is necessary as bedbugs can be difficult to eradicate and insecticide resistance is common.
    • Fleas — advise the person that flea bites are often associated with contact with domestic pets (especially cats and dogs) and that animals should be examined and treated if necessary. If the person has recently moved house, flea infestations may remain from previous pet owners.
    • Lice — see the CKS topics on Head lice and Pubic lice for information on treatment of symptoms and eradication.
    • Scabies — see the CKS topic on Scabies  for information on treatment of symptoms and eradication.
  • If the person has a transient localised reaction to the bite or sting:
    • Usually no treatment other than simple first aid is required.
      • Oral analgesics such as paracetamol and ibuprofen are often recommended to ease pain but evidence in support of these treatments is lacking.
      • For more information on prescribing paracetamol and ibuprofen see the CKS topic on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain.
    • Oral antihistamines (such as chlorphenamine [sedating]) or topical corticosteroids (such as hydrocortisone 1%) may help reduce itching associated with cutaneous reactions but use is generally off-label and good quality evidence in support of use is lacking.
      • For more information on prescribing antihistamines and topical corticosteroids see the CKS topics on Urticaria and Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes respectively.
    • Topical antipruritics (such as crotamitin), topical antihistamines and topical anaesthetics sold over-the-counter are of uncertain value in the treatment of insect bites and may themselves cause irritant skin reactions.
  • If the person has a large local reaction
    • Oral antihistamines and/or corticosteroids are often used in treatment of large local reactions to insect bites and stings but use is generally off-label and supporting evidence is lacking.
      • Do not prescribe corticosteroids if there is a possibility that the insect bite or sting may be infected.
      • If prescribing corticosteroids be aware of potential adverse effects and use the lowest dose for the shortest period.
      • For more information on prescribing oral antihistamines and corticosteroids see the CKS topics on Urticaria and Corticosteroids - oral.
    • Discuss the need for referral to secondary care with an allergy specialist and arrange follow up to ensure resolution of symptoms.
  • If secondary infection develops:
    • Treat cellulitis in primary care with oral antibiotics in accordance with local prescribing protocols. Consider the need for admission if cellulitis is severe or worsening despite management in primary care — for further information see the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute.
    • Arrange follow up to ensure resolution of symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Insect bite and sting prevention
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advise the person to:

  • Take sensible precautions, especially if they have had a bad reaction to a sting or bite in the past:
    • In general:
      • Keep skin covered with long sleeved clothing, trousers, and socks — brightly coloured clothing and flowery prints can attract insects. Avoid walking outside barefoot or in sandals.
      • Avoid strongly scented perfumes, soaps, shampoos, and deodorants.
      • Avoid areas where there is a greater chance of being stung such as outdoor settings with food and drink, compost and rubbish bins that attract stinging insects. If eating outside, take care when drinking from opaque containers and straws.
      • Ensure that known or suspected insect nests (such as wasps) close to the home are removed by trained professionals.
      • Keep insecticides approved for use on stinging insects readily available to kill stinging insects from a distance if necessary — stinging insects are not affected by insect repellents.
    • If tick-infested areas cannot be avoided:
      • Cover exposed skin with long-sleeved shirts and trousers tucked into socks (light coloured fabrics are useful as it is easier to see ticks against a light background).
      • Consider using an insect repellent containing DEET (diethyl-toluamide) — available over-the-counter.
      • Inspect skin at regular intervals throughout the day and at the end of the day and remove any attached ticks— thoroughly check children’s head, scalp and neck areas.
      • Check clothes and pets for ticks.

Patient information leaflets are available from:

  • Public Health England — Ticks and your health - Information about tick bite risks and prevention.
  • The Anaphylaxis Campaign — Insect sting allergy – the facts.

[Golden et al, 2011; Due et al, 2013; PHE, 2013]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of insect bites and stings in primary care are based on the clinical guideline Stinging Insect Hypersensitivity: A Practice Parameter Update 2011 [Golden et al, 2011], the Public Health England Publication Ticks and your health - Information about tick bite risks and prevention [PHE, 2013], expert opinion in the British National Formulary (BNF) [BNF 71, 2016], a dermatology textbook [Monsel et al, 2016], review articles [Doggett and Russell, 2009; DTB, 2012; Juckett, 2013; BMJ Best Practice, 2016], and NICE guideline Insect bites and stings: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2020]. 

Sting removal
  • The recommendation on method of removing a sting is based on expert opinion in clinical guideline [Golden et al, 2011] and dermatology textbook [Monsel et al, 2016].
Tick removal
  • The recommendation on method of removing ticks is based on expert opinion from Public Health England [PHE, 2013], a dermatology textbook [Monsel et al, 2016] and review articles [Due et al, 2013; Juckett, 2013].
    • Cases of tick anaphylaxis have been reported. If the person is known to have had a previous systemic reaction to ticks removal should be done in accident and emergency. Disturbing the tick may cause it to inject further allergens and trigger a systemic reaction [van Nunen, 2015].
Use of antipruritics
  • The BNF states that preparations containing the antipruritic crotamiton are sometimes used but of uncertain value in treatment of insect bites [BNF 71, 2016].
    • One double blind study of pruritic dermatoses (n = 31) found that crotamiton was no more effective than its vehicle as antipuritic [Smith et al, 1984].
  • The BNF states that calamine preparations are of little value for the treatment of insect bites and stings [BNF 71, 2016].
Use of antihistamines
  • The recommendation on use of oral antihistamines is based on the clinical guideline [Golden et al, 2011] and expert opinion in a dermatology textbook [Monsel et al, 2016] and review article [DTB, 2012] however all sources state that although use of antihistamines is common in management of insect bites supporting evidence is lacking.
    • Oral antihistamines
      • The use of many oral antihistamines in the treatment of insect bites and stings is off-label.
      • The BNF states that short-term treatment with a sedating antihistamine may help in insect stings and in intractable pruritus where sedation is desirable.
      • CKS could not identify any recent good quality clinical trials to support the use of antihistamines for the treatment of insect bites and stings.
    • Topical antihistamines
      • The BNF states that topical antihistamines have limited efficacy and may themselves cause sensitization [BNF 71, 2016].
Use of corticosteroids
  • The recommendation on use of corticosteroids in treatment of insect bite and sting reactions is based on the clinical guideline [Golden et al, 2011] and expert opinion in a dermatology textbook [Monsel et al, 2016] and review article [DTB, 2012] however, all sources are clear that although use in this context is common, supporting evidence is lacking.
    • Topical corticosteroids
      • CKS could find no trial evidence for topical hydrocortisone. However, it is licensed for the treatment of insect bite reactions, and a short course is often used to reduce inflammation and itching after an insect bite or sting [BNF 71, 2016].
      • The BNF states that for insect bite and sting reactions, a short course of a topical corticosteroid is appropriate.
    • Oral corticosteroids
      • CKS could not identify any published randomized controlled trials assessing the efficacy of oral corticosteroids in the treatment of insect bite and sting reactions, although they are widely used in this context.
      • The AAAAI states that although there are no controlled trials, prompt use of oral corticosteroids is effective in limiting swelling in patients with previous history of large local reactions [Golden et al, 2011].
